paragraphs.text: Solid State Communications Crystal electric field effects and thermal expansion of rare-earth hexaborides

Anomalies in the magnetic contribution to the thermal expansion coefficients Δβ(T)of the CeB 6 , PrB 6 , and NdB 6 hexaborides in the range of 5-300 K were found by comparison with diamagnetic LaB 6 .

The characteristic of the anomalies was the same in all the studied borides: a distinct peak at low temperatures, followed by a broad maximum at higher temperatures (50-100 K), then a decrease and transition to the region of negative values as the temperature increases further.
The features of Δβ(T) are explained by the effects of the magnetic order (sharp low temperature peaks) and the crystal electric field (CEF).
The β CEF (T) dependencies were calculated using Raman and neutron scattering data on the splitting of the rare-earth (RE) ions R 3+ f-level by the CEF.
A satisfactory consistency between the values of β CEF (T) and Δβ(T)was obtained for the studied hexaborides.
Additionally, we determined the values of the Grüneisen parameter γ i that correspond to the transition between the ground and excited multiplets of R 3+ ions f-level splitting.
Hexaborides Thermal expansion Crystal electric field Low temperatures
Hexaborides of rare-earth (RE) elements (RB 6 , where R stands for the RE metal) are a group of compounds whose properties have recently received considerable attention.

Most work dedicated to studying the properties of RE hexaborides has dealt with different aspects of the transitions of their magnetic subsystems into an ordered state when the temperature decreases [1-10] as well as their electronic properties .

Calorimetric studies, including those in which high magnetic fields were used , have enabled to reveal the characteristic of the ground state of R 3+ ions in hexaborides, the type of magnetic ordering, and the thermodynamic characteristics (enthalpy and entropy) of phase transformations.

Studies of the thermal expan- sion of RE hexaborides revealed sharp anomalies in the temperature dependence of the lattice parameters at the phase transi- tion temperatures (5-30 K) and broader anomalies at higher tempera- tures (50-300 K).
In this study, we address the nature of the thermal expansion anomalies in RE hexaborides.

We have investigated the effect of magnetic phase transitions and crystal electric field (CEF) on thermal expansion of the hexaborides using the experimental data obtained earlier with the participation of one of the authors (V.V.N.) of the present paper.
Let us consider a system of non-interacting RE ions with the ground state split by a CEF .

Depending on the E i values and the γ iCEF Grüneisen parameter, the CEF can elevate or reduce β(Т) in different parts of the temperature range.

We analysed the results of x-ray studies on the lattice parameters for LaB 6 , CeB 6 , PrB 6 , and NdB 6 in the temperature range of 5-300 K using the schemes of splitting the ground f-level RE ions in hexaborides obtained by Raman and neutron spectroscopy .

Apparently, the sharp low-temperature peaks Δβ T ( ) RB6 are due to magnetic phase transitions in hexaborides (T = 2.3 K N CeB6 ; T = 6.9 K N B Pr 6 ; T = 8.6 K N NdB6

We assume that the higher temperature broad anomalies of Δβ T ( ) RB6 (the maxima being about 30-50 K, the minima being about 100-200 K) could be understood as the effect of CEF on R 3+ ion f-levels in the hexaborides.
To verify this hypothesis, we used data on CEF- splitting for CeB 6 , [30] PrB 6 , and NdB .

The temperatures of maxima in Δβ T ( ) RB6 and Δβ T ( ) CEF are correlated with the corresponding δ 1 splitting values .
Thus, the following conclusion can be drawn: the high-temperature anomalies of CeB 6 , PrB 6 , and NdB 6 hexaboride thermal expansion are due to the effect of CEF on R 3+ ions system.

Large values of the Grüneisen parameter γ iCEF (up to several tens) and the same distribution of signs in γ iCEF for all compounds in the studied group are the characteristic features of CEF effects on RB 6 thermal expansion. We conclude that γ > 0 CEF 1 , a positive contribution to the thermal expansion, corresponds to the transition to the first excited multiplet, whereas γ < 0 CEF 2 , a negative contribution to the β T ( )
values, corresponds to the transition to the next multiplet.
The CEF has a significant effect on the magnetic, electric, and thermal properties of a material in a wide range of low temperatures.
The present study is one of the first attempt to determine a reasons which lead to thermal expansion anomalies of RE-hexaborides at elevated temperatures.

It was found that the experimentally identified anomalous regularities of the temperature dependences of the thermal expansion of rare-earth hexaborides at moderately low temperatures can be due to CEF effect on the system of R 3+ paramagnetic ions.
CEF- splitting of the f-levels in RE hexaborides leads to the Schottky heat capacity contribution and to thermal expansion anomalies.
Deviations of thermal characteristics of RE hexaborides from their regular (lattice) values can be calculated using the established schemes of CEF- splitting.
The approach used in this article can be applied to analyze the anomalies of thermal properties of magnets of different classes.
